Key Arguments: The legislation is seen as an overreach by the government to control falsehoods on the internet.
Concerns that the bill would limit free expression and censor opinions rather than reduce falsehoods.
The government is not holding itself to the same standards it wants to impose on the public.
The bill could lead to the erosion of freedom of expression and contribute to cancel culture.
The subjective nature of determining 'hate speech' or 'serious harm' could lead to false accusations and stifling of debate.
The proposal gives too much power to ACMA, which could dictate what is considered truth.
The requirement for social media companies to store and provide user data to ACMA is seen as invasive.
The bill lacks transparency and accountability and is viewed as against human rights.
Notable Quotes: This seems to reflect that it is really based on censoring peopleâ€™s opinions and not trying to reduce falsehoods.
This can also lead to a further eroding of freedom of having different views and expressing them.
This proposal relies on a government appointed ACMA having the power to dictate what they believe is truth.
The government would be the ultimate authority of truth via ACMA.
